awd_titl_txt: EBP: Bringing AP Computer Science Principles to Students with Learning Disabilities and/or an ADHD: The Hidden Underrepresented Group
awd_abstract_narration:
This study aims to expand participation in computer science by ensuring that students with learning differences (students with learning disabilities and/or an Attention Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD)) can successfully participate in computer science courses in general, and AP Computer Science Principles (CSP) courses in particular. An interdisciplinary team from Outlier Research & Evaluation (a research group at the Center for Elementary Mathematics and Science Education (CEMSE) at the University of Chicago), and the Wolcott School (a school in Chicago for students with learning differences) will apply their expertise in education research, special education, psychology, pedagogy, and computer science (CS) content to: identify the challenges students with learning differences face as they engage with computer science concepts and computational practices; derive solutions for addressing those challenges, and; test adaptations and accommodations that address those challenges for two AP Computer Science Principles (CSP )curricula in development: Beauty and Joy of Computing for New York City (BJC4NYC); and Code.org's CS Principles. Findings from this project will take a first step toward ensuring that this often overlooked student population can fully participate in CS education. The project is timely, as the College Board is preparing to launch the new AP CSP course in the fall of 2016. The findings of this foundational study will be crucial to ensuring that students who learn differently are not excluded. 

To accomplish this goal, the Outlier and Wolcott School team will pursue the following research questions: (1) What are the learning and teaching concerns regarding making high school CS education in general, and AP CSP in particular, accessible to students with learning differences?; (2) What specific adaptations and accommodations are needed to make CSP courses in general and BJC4NYC and CS Principles in particular accessible to students with learning differences?; and (3) To what extent do students with learning differences successfully complete the AP CSP course and demonstrate positive attitudes about their experience? To answer these questions, the project team will: a) identify lesson adaptations generally associated with specific learning disabilities and an ADHD, and consider their application in CS education; b) generate and test adaptations and accommodations for select CSP lessons; c) derive a set of design principles for teaching CS to students with learning differences; d) work with CSP developers to permanently incorporate adaptations and accommodations into their materials; and e) broadly disseminate findings, instructional guidance and other findings about adjustments for students with learning differences. The team will employ a mixed-methods research design using data collected through classroom observations; teacher written feedback and interviews; and student written feedback, self-assessments, questionnaire responses, focus groups and interviews. The study will support efforts to generate a wide-scale infrastructure for high school CS education by taking steps to generate knowledge about what is needed to include this as yet unreached group in computer science education, provide specific guidance about ways to include students who learn differently in CSP, and demonstrate the importance and merits of working to advance this dimension of broadening participation.

por.por_cntn:
Overview: The key purpose of the study, known as the CSP and Students Who Learn Differently study (October 2015 – May 2018), was to contribute to broadening participation efforts in computer science (CS) with a focus on students with disabilities. In particular, this project sought to explore ways to make high school CS more accessible to students with specific learning disabilities (like those related to reading, written expression, language, and math) and attention disorders (like attention deficit hyperactivity disorder, or ADHD). The study has contributed to the field and the growing attention to CS education by a) identifying aspects of the new Computer Science Principles (CSP) course that many be challenging for students with learning disabilities and attention disorders, b) developing and iterating on strategies to enable teachers to facilitate a range of high school CS learning experiences inclusive of these students, and c) adding to the CS education community’s toolbox of resources to equitably include those with learning and attention disorders in CS. The close collaboration of experienced practitioners and student learners at the Wolcott School in Chicago (a high school for students with diagnosed learning and attention disorders), and education researchers at Outlier Research & Evaluation at the University of Chicago was a critical element of the work. In collaboratively asking how we might address this classroom-based problem that teachers face, we strove to create a balanced foundation for future research to enable more of these students who learn differently to engage with, and succeed in computing education.

 

Intellectual Merit: It is estimated that 1 in 5 school-age youth in the U.S have learning and attention disorders although only a small portion of those students are formally identified with a disability in school and receive learning supports under the Individuals with Disabilities and Education Act, or IDEA (Horowitz, Rawe, and Whittaker, 2017). These learners spend 80% of the school day in general education settings, including CS classes. Yet there is little scholarly literature about how to make CS learning accessible for these students, and particularly high school learners. Using data collected in the study, combined with research in non-CS areas and the experience of Wolcott learning specialists, the team created lesson adjustment and general inclusive instructional practice guides for CSP, and other high school CS teachers, mapped to typical CS classroom activities, to help guide teaching and learning in CS classrooms.

 

Study findings highlighted a rich description of student experiences in CSP, challenges faced by learners, and research-informed teaching practices to support students who learn differently in CS. For example, in 1:1 every-other-week interviews with 13 CSP students in study year 2, we found that the majority of partner students (10 of 13) frequently described challenges related to focus, attention, and pacing of the class (“With my ADHD, it’s harder for me to sit there, focus, and try to follow along unless I’m actually doing something.”), which informed the team’s emphasis on guidance for teachers specific to activities that require strength in skills related to these areas. Guides generated through study findings like these will be a resource for the CS education community working toward “CS for All” including classroom teachers that aim to reach a diverse range of learners, CS curriculum providers developing and iterating the next version of instructional materials and building teacher professional development, and informal CS education providers seeking to reach and engage the next wave of computing learners and professionals. The study served as a first step toward further work to collaborate across research and practice to investigate useful and practical ways to enable teachers to develop richly inclusive teaching and learning environments accessible to a wide range of students, particularly those with learning disabilities and attention disorders.    

 

Broader Impacts: The CSP and Students Who Learn Differently study has raised the awareness of the need to intentionally consider learners with learning disabilities and attention disorders, and informed the CS community (teachers, curriculum developers, researchers) about strategies and instructional supports for students who learn differently. A notable contribution has been the initial development of practitioner-focused teaching resources to help guide both new, and veteran high school CS teachers in classroom teaching and learning, inclusive of students with learning disabilities and attention disorders for five CSP provider groups (Beauty and Joy of Computing, Code.org, Mobile CSP, Quorum, UTeach), and high school CS teachers in general. The team has also produced numerous practitioner and researcher-focused webinar and conference presentations, blog posts, and several scholarly publications. All of the team’s efforts have focused squarely on making progress toward including a yet-unreached and underrepresented group of learners in high school CS and beyond, ensuring actual student voices are included in needs assessment and instructional materials development efforts, and ultimately demonstrating the importance and merits of working to advance this dimension of broadening participation.
